bestBHT.bht: Jesus began to pray repeatedly, falling on the ground in distress for the approaching hour. He had long anticipated this hour and dreaded it, hoping for an alternative that would spare him from enduring the suffering. As he prayed in this posture, he sought for a way to be excused from the impending trial, if it were possible, while still bringing salvation to his people.

Marvin Vincent: Prayed [προσηυχετο] . Imperfect tense : began to pray.
Philip Schaff: Mark 14:35. The hour might pass away from him. The ‘hour’ representing the specific conflict of that hour in the garden. See Matthew 26:46.
Archibald T. Robertson: Fell on the ground (επιπτεν επ της γης). Descriptive imperfect. See him falling."
Prayed (προσηυχετο). Imperfect, prayed repeatedly or inchoative, began to pray. Either makes good sense."
The hour (η ωρα). Jesus had long looked forward to this 'hour' and had often mentioned it...Now he dreads it, surely a human trait that all can understand.
John Gill: He fell on his face to the ground, which was a praying posture.
The supplication Christ made in this posture was, that it were possible, the hour might pass from him.
That is, that it might pass without his enduring them, if there was any possibility of excusing him, and of his people's being saved without them.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 14:35, Jesus began to pray repeatedly or started praying. He fell on the ground, a praying posture, showing his distress and dread for the approaching hour. This moment is significant because Jesus had long anticipated this hour and had frequently mentioned it, so it is understandable that he would feel human hesitation. His supplication was that, if possible, the hour could pass without him having to endure the suffering, hoping for an alternative that would still lead to the salvation of his people.

Jesus, in Mark 14:35, began to pray repeatedly, falling on the ground in distress for the approaching hour. He had long anticipated this hour and dreaded it, which anyone can empathize with. His supplication was that, if possible, the hour could pass without his suffering, while still ensuring the salvation of his people. So, in this praying posture, he sought for an alternative that would fulfill his mission without the intense pain and sacrifice that awaited him.

Jesus began to pray repeatedly, falling on the ground in distress for the approaching hour. He had long anticipated this hour and dreaded it, hoping for an alternative that would spare him from enduring the suffering. As he prayed in this posture, he sought for a way to be excused from the impending trial, if it were possible, while still bringing salvation to his people.

Jesus, in this verse, began to pray repeatedly and fell on the ground in distress for the hour that he had long anticipated. He dreaded the approaching trial and hoped for a possible alternative, seeking to be excused from the suffering. His supplication was for the hour to pass without enduring the pain, while still ensuring the salvation of his people. As he assumed a posture of prayer, Jesus fervently sought a way for his purpose to be fulfilled without the inherent tribulations.

Jesus, in this passage, began to pray repeatedly, falling on the ground in distress for the impending hour. He had long anticipated this hour and now dreaded it, seeking an alternative way to spare himself from the inevitable suffering. His earnest supplication was for the hour to pass without enduring the trials, while still ensuring the salvation of his people. In this humble posture, Jesus fervently sought the possibility of fulfilling his mission without the arduous sacrifice that awaited him.
